Fixed position artillery units that pack quite a punch, they are nevertheless very weak if engaged in melee.
With a long range and able to cause great damage, field artillery can be moved slowly around the battlefield, but are very weak if engaged in melee.
Huge siege engines perfect for knocking down walls and gatehouses.
Although they are versatile units protected by shields, melee cavalry are weak against more specialised units.
Fast moving and with a long range, missile cavalry are great at harassing their enemies, but weak if pinned down in melee.
The hammer to the infantry of any army, they are devastating when charged into the flank or rear of enemies.
Fast moving units with a wide turning circle, they can punch through weak enemy units. They are vulnerable if pinned down in combat.
These are small units that protect the general whilst he gets on with his job.
There's nothing quite like an elephant to make a hole in an enemy line. Flaming projectiles and javelins are the best way to counter them.
Frontline soldiers trained for hand-to-hand combat with their enemies.
Long range units who provide support for melee units, but are themselves generally weak in close combat.
Long pikes make these troops deadly from the front but vulnerable if flanked. They are highly effective against cavalry.
Solid defensive infantry protected by shields, they are very good when ranged against cavalry.
These ships can do a lot of damage from long range, but can be neutralised by boarding and ramming.
Perfect for taking out enemy ships, but have to close quickly and board to be successful.
Enemy ships can be showered with their projectiles, but they must steer clear of enemy melee ships.
Slow but with plenty of space, they do their job well. Just remember that they aren't warships.
Nothing says "surprise!" like unleashing animals on the battlefield.
